results.title: Space filling curves (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: William Hansard, Topology Films Project and Education Development Center
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Using computer animation the concept of a limit curve is graphically portrayed as a sequence of approximate curves and applied to the construction of space filling curves; curves which pass through every point in a square.

results.title: Family Court
results.creator_credit: Peter Campbell, Diane Sundin, Family Court of Australia and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 58 of Series “English at work”.
This video explains the role of the Family Court in divorce cases. It explains the grounds for applying for divorce, and the issues involved in a divorce in Australia. It also explains options offered by the Family Court after an application for divorce has been made: the structure of Information sessions, conciliation conferences, and court counsellors to help resolve differences in the main areas of dispute; children and property.

results.title: Prejudice: equality ...at what price
results.creator_credit: Ian Munro, Pamela Williams and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A provocative docu-drama portraying two cases of female discrimination experienced by separate women from unrelated backgrounds. Jessica, a newspaper photographer is subjected to a campaign of sexual harassment and Letitia is denied a promotion and subjected to humiliating racist comments from her colleagues. The stories are linked by the Anti-Discrimination Board, established to investigate and conciliate complaints of prejudice and discrimination. Combines the use of actors and “actual” professional people including Officers of the ADB, union representatives and members of the legal profession play themselves.

results.title: Communicating change
results.creator_credit: Diane Sundin, Australia Post and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “English at work”.
This program examines the issues of managing change in the workplace. It shows the importance for everyone in the workplace to understand what changes are going to happen, why they are happening and how everyone will be affected by them.

results.title: Orthogonal projection (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Jay Hines, Don Gangloff, Art Landy, Allen Downs and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Introduces an elementary transformation involving triangles transformed into a problem involving conics. Uses certain fundamental geometric notions such as division of line segments into given ratios, in variance under transformations, conic sections etc. which are encountered in other parts of geometry.

results.title: Balls of Steel for PC
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM in CD jewel case with insert and manual
results.brief_description:
Balls of Steel is a top-down pinball computer game that features five fully-animated pinball tables, each with its own theme, missions, and special bonuses. One of the tables is themed on Duke Nukem, a franchise that Balls of Steel’s publisher, Apogee Software, developed. This tie-in continues to Duke Nukem series itself, where the pinball game appears in several releases.

Balls of Steel plays on a top-down scrolling screen, with an animated dot matrix display at the bottom mimicking the displays of actual pinball tables. As with its real-life counterpart, it shows the player score and animated graphics. Each table can also be viewed in its entirety. High scores are awarded with a “powerball” bonus mode, and could be posted on the “WorldScores” website for a global ranking, although this feature has since been discontinued.

results.title: Projective generation of conics (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Allen Downs, Bob Nelson and College Geometry Project, University of Minnesota
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Introduces the eccentricity definition, then focuses on projective definitions devoid of metric notion implying the construction of a conic by straight edge alone. Shows methods of construction developed by Pascal, Malaurin, Braikenridge, Poncelet and Steiner. The logical relationship between the methods is demonstrated.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Allen Downs, Bob Nelson and College Geometry Project, University of Minnesota
results.description:

results.title: Journey to the centre of a triangle (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Katharine Cornwell, Bruce Cornwell and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Examines the incentre, circumcentre, the centroid, and the orthocentre of triangles. Visual constructions illustrate each kind of centre, and several examples are used to show how each is determined. Without narration. For beginning geometry students.

results.title: Dihedral kaleidoscopes (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Art Landy, University of Minnesota and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Presents basic ideas of symmetry by exhibiting dihedral groups by reflections of intersecting mirrors. From reflection in a single mirror the film proceeds to study the surprising effects and beautiful patterns that can be produced with two or three mirrors. Observations on the general case are made as well as on the limiting case in which two mirrors are parallel.

results.title: Central similarities (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Allen Downs, Jay Hines and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Dilatations (central similarities) are introduced to solve the problem of inscribing an ellipse to touch the sides of a given triangle at their midpoints. Coordinate geometry is also introduced to solve a subsidiary problem stressing the importance of the geometric interpretation of algebraic equations. Narrated by Delbert Ball.
